tips.text: Hunger pangs are often habit signals — most waves pass within 15–20 minutes.
Your body is simply responding to routine. This feeling will fade as you adapt.
Remember: hunger comes in waves, not constant streams. Ride this one out.
You're not actually starving — your body has plenty of stored energy to use.
Try a glass of water — it can help reset hunger cues and fill your stomach.
Sip some herbal tea or black coffee to satisfy the oral fixation of eating.
Add a pinch of sea salt to water — dehydration can disguise itself as hunger.
Try sparkling water with lemon — the bubbles and flavor can be surprisingly satisfying.
Go for a short walk — movement makes cravings fade faster.
Do 10 jumping jacks or push-ups — physical activity redirects your focus.
Step outside for fresh air — changing your environment can reset your mindset.
Try gentle stretching — it activates your parasympathetic nervous system.
Take 5 deep breaths and notice: is this true hunger or just habit?
Observe the sensation without judgment — hunger is just information, not a command.
Focus on your 'why' — remember the benefits you're working toward.
Practice the '10-minute rule' — tell yourself you'll eat in 10 minutes, then reassess.
Morning hunger is often the strongest — your body expects breakfast out of habit.
Try black coffee or tea — caffeine can naturally suppress appetite.
Remember: skipping breakfast won't slow your metabolism as once believed.
It's lunchtime — if you're hungry, remember this wave will fade. Try water or a 10-min walk.
Midday hunger often peaks around your usual lunch hour — this is normal and temporary.
Keep busy with a task or project — mental engagement is a powerful appetite suppressant.
Evening hunger can feel social and emotional — acknowledge these feelings without acting.
Try an evening walk instead of dinner — movement and fresh air work wonders.
Remember: you've made it this far today. You're stronger than you think.

early.name: Early Fast (0-16 hours)
early.description: Tips for the beginning of your fast when habits are strongest

tips.text: You're in the habit-breaking phase — hunger now is mostly psychological.
Stay hydrated and keep busy — the first 16 hours are about breaking routine.
Each hour you complete makes the next one easier. You're building momentum.

transition.name: Transition Phase (16-24 hours)
transition.description: Tips for when your body starts shifting to fat-burning mode

tips.text: Your body is starting to switch to fat-burning mode — hunger may actually decrease soon.
You're entering the metabolic switching phase — power through this transition.
Many people find hunger subsides significantly after 20-24 hours.

extended.name: Extended Fast (24+ hours)
extended.description: Tips for longer fasts when ketosis deepens

tips.text: You're likely in ketosis now — many report decreased appetite at this stage.
Focus on electrolytes — hunger might actually be your body needing minerals.
You've entered the zone where fasting becomes easier — trust your body's wisdom.
